citations.narrative:
The facility did not have complete disposition records for one llama and one parakeet. Acquisition and disposition records,
including offspring born at the facility, are necessary to accurately track and identify animals being used in regulated
activities, as well as aid in the detection of movement of animals upon relocation to a new site. The facility shall make,
keep, and maintain records of acquisition/disposition of all animals that fully and correctly disclose the required
information.

On August 31st, the attending veterinarian conducted a necropsy after a parakeet was found dead within the aviary. Upon
visual assessment, the facility deduced that the parakeet had succumb to injuries due to predation by a hawk. While the
facility is certain the hawk was not able to enter the aviary, it was still able to access the bird. Ongoing threats due to
predation are a concern for all birds housed in the enclosure, as these opportunities contribute to unnecessary stress,
injuries, fear, and occurrences for trauma for all of the birds on-hand.
The facility must ensure that animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not
cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

One opened bag of primate biscuits were stored in the freezer, where the biscuits contained therein had began to appear
discolored. Additionally, chemical agents used for cleaning and disinfecting (including two containers of bleach) were
stored in the backup animal areas of the ring-tailed lemur exhibit, sitting beside food items used for enrichment purposes.
Storing opened bags of food in containers with lids lessens its exposure to contamination, vermin, and spoilage when
confined in its own container. All food and bedding supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow
cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Open supplies not in use must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly
fitting lids to prevent spoilage and contamination. Substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates, but are required for
normal husbandry practices, must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas unless kept in cabinets.

One container of marshmallow creme used for the chimpanzees has expired. This food item has been used to administer
medications for the chimpanzees at the facility, with the facility representatives unaware the date had passed until noted
on the inspection.
Feeding food items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld
and preserved. Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive
value to maintain all animals in good health.

Bags of bird feed in the food room were stacked and stored directly against the walls. Storing food supplies away from the
walls and off the ground helps mitigate opportunities for vermin infiltration, while supporting efficient cleaning and
monitoring practices for all food supplies stored before they are dispensed out to the avian species on-hand.
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects against
deterioration, spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the
walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. All food must be stored in a manner that prevents
deterioration of its nutritive value.

The outdoor enclosures housing one wild turkey and one Harris hawk did not provide sufficient shelter from the wind. The
turkey’s enclosure did not provide any opportunities to inhibit wind entering the exhibit, while the Harris hawk enclosure
provided limited barriers to offset wind gusts that would enter the enclosure.
Inappropriate shelter exposes birds to extreme weather conditions which could cause discomfort, illness, or distress to the
animals. The facility must provide an adequate shelter to protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions that is
large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct sunlight,
precipitation, or wind.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by December 10th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility did not have complete disposition records for one llama and one parakeet. Acquisition and disposition records, 
including offspring born at the facility, are necessary to accurately track and identify animals being used in regulated 
activities, as well as aid in the detection of movement of animals upon relocation to a new site. The facility shall make, 
keep, and maintain records of acquisition/disposition of all animals that fully and correctly disclose the required 
information. 
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On August 31st, the attending veterinarian  conducted a necropsy after a parakeet was found dead within the aviary. Upon 
visual assessment, the facility deduced that the parakeet had succumb to injuries due to predation by a hawk. While the 
facility is certain the hawk was not able to enter the aviary, it was still able to access the bird. Ongoing threats due to 
predation are a concern for all birds housed in the enclosure, as these opportunities contribute to unnecessary stress, 
injuries, fear, and occurrences for trauma for all of the birds on-hand. 
 
The facility must ensure that animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not 
cause trauma, overheating,  excessive cooling, behavioral  stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
One opened bag of primate biscuits were stored in the freezer, where the biscuits contained therein had began to appear 
discolored. Additionally, chemical agents used for cleaning and disinfecting (including two containers of bleach) were 
stored in the backup animal areas of the ring-tailed lemur exhibit, sitting beside food items used for enrichment purposes.  
Storing opened bags of food in containers with lids lessens its exposure to contamination, vermin, and spoilage when 
confined in its own container. All food and bedding supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow 
cleaning underneath  and around the supplies. Open supplies not in use must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly 
fitting lids to prevent spoilage and contamination. Substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates, but are required for 
normal husbandry practices, must not be stored in food storage and preparation  areas unless kept in cabinets.

3.82(a) 
   
Feeding. 
One container of marshmallow creme used for the chimpanzees has expired. This food item has been used to administer 
medications for the chimpanzees at the facility, with the facility representatives  unaware the date had passed until noted 
on the inspection.  
Feeding food items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld 
and preserved.  Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive 
value to maintain all animals in good health. 
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Bags of bird feed in the food room were stacked and stored directly against the walls. Storing food supplies away from the 
walls and off the ground helps mitigate opportunities for vermin infiltration, while supporting efficient cleaning and 
monitoring practices for all food supplies stored before they are dispensed out to the avian species on-hand. 
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects against 
deterioration, spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the 
walls, to allow cleaning underneath  and around the supplies. All food must be stored in a manner that prevents 
deterioration of its nutritive value. 
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
The outdoor enclosures housing one wild turkey and one Harris hawk did not provide sufficient shelter from the wind. The 
turkey’s enclosure did not provide any opportunities to inhibit wind entering the exhibit, while the Harris hawk enclosure 
provided  limited barriers to offset wind gusts that would enter the enclosure. 
 
Inappropriate  shelter exposes birds to extreme weather conditions which could cause discomfort, illness, or distress to the 
animals. The facility must provide  an adequate shelter to protect the birds from any adverse  weather conditions that is 
large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent  their discomfort from direct sunlight, 
precipitation, or wind. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by December 10th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
